newsitem.title: UK: Russia Eurobond sells out amid improved sentiment.
newsitem.headline: Russia Eurobond sells out amid improved sentiment.

text.p: Russia borrowed $2.0 billion in the international capital markets on Thursday, and bankers said the successful transaction reflected improved sentiment towards the country.

"Russia was a complete blow-out," a banker involved in the transaction said. "Sentiment towards Russia has become increasingly more positive, and they (Russians) could have raised even more than they did today."
The deal, modern Russia's third since its market debut last November, ranks among the largest Eurobonds ever, and dealers reported huge demand for paper after a series of roadshows worldwide.
Reformers Anatoly Chubais and Boris Nemstov's appointments to government has boosted foreign investor confidence that reforms will be pushed through.
Russia doubled both the size and maturity of a dollar bond launched last year and managed to raise funds more cheaply.

Thursday's 10-year bond was launched with a 10.00-percent coupon, a key psychological level. Double-digit coupons are rare in the current low interest rate environment and are particularly attractive to retail investors.
The deal was priced to yield 3.75 percentage points over U.S. Treasuries. J.P. Morgan Securities and SBC Warburg were joint lead managers.

Russia first tapped the international capital markets in November 1996 with a $1.0 billion five-year bond, priced to yield 3.45 percentage points over Treasuries. It was trading at 2.70 points over on Thursday.
In March, it raised 2.0 billion marks ($1.2 billion) via a seven-year bond. Thursyday's deal brought the 1997 total to around $3.2 billion.
Last Friday, Russian deputy finance minister Mikhail Kasyanov told a news conference it would borrow up to $3.5 billion from international bond markets this year.
That figure was based on Russia's also launching a global dollar bond in the second half of the year.
"(Thursday's deal) has given Russia the flexibility to be more opportunistic if they want to do another deal this year, partly as pre-funding for 1998," a banker at a European bank said.
Kasyanov also said Russia would raise $3.0-3.5 billion internationally in 1998. "That is an appropriate amount for us using this source of funding," he said.
